intro: Acaena confertissima var. intermedia, commonly known as the New Zealand thistle, is a perennial shrub native to New Zealand. It features dense clusters of spiny, woody stems covered in soft, woolly hairs. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in late winter to early spring. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and often have a slightly serrated edge. It is adapted to grow in a variety of soil types and is commonly found in coastal and subalpine regions.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena confertissima var. intermedia is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the Canterbury and Otago regions. This plant typically grows in open, disturbed habitats such as roadsides, gravelly soils, and dry grasslands. It is adapted to a range of soil types but prefers well-drained conditions. The species is known for its spiny fruits and is part of the rose family, Rosaceae.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena confertissima var. intermedia was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European colonization efforts in the 19th century. This plant is commonly found in disturbed areas such as roadsides, pastures, and along riverbanks. It has since become naturalized and is considered a weed in some parts of the country. Its spread has raised concerns due to its ability to outcompete native vegetation.
